title.text: Umelb: Cross-lingual Textual Entailment with Word Alignment and String Similarity Features

abstractContent.text: This paper describes The University of Mel-bourne NLP group submission to the Cross-lingual Textual Entailment shared task, our first tentative attempt at the task.

entities.text: The University of Mel-bourne NLP group

abstractContent.text: The approach involves using parallel corpora and automatic word alignment to align text fragment pairs, and statistics based on unaligned words as features to classify items as forward and backward before a compositional combination into the final four classes, as well as experiments with additional string similarity features .

introductionContent.text: Cross-lingual Textual Entailment (CLTE) (  proposes the task of automatically identifying the kind of relation that exists between pairs of semantically-related text fragments written in two distinct languages, a variant of the traditional Recognizing Textual Entailment (RTE) task).

introductionContent.text: The task targets the cross-lingual content synchronization scenario proposed in.

Compositional classification can be used by training two distinct binary classifiers for forward and backward entailment classification, before combining labels into the four final entailment categories that now include bidirectional and no entailment labels.

The most similar previous work to this work is the crosslingual approach of the FBK system ( ) from Semeval 2012 ( , in which the entailment classification is obtained without translating T1 into T2 for the SpanishEnglish language pair.

We apply the cross-lingual approach to German-English and instead of crosslingual matching features, we use Giza++ () and Moses () to automatically word align text fragment pairs to compute statistics of unaligned words.
In addition, we include some additional experiments using string similarity features.
